section_a_workflow_definition.q02_trigger_event: Tenant submits maintenance request via portal
section_a_workflow_definition.q03_business_objective: Schedule technician visit within SLA window
section_a_workflow_definition.q04_end_condition: Appointment confirmed with tenant and technician assigned

section_c_systems_handoffs.q11_manual_data_transfers: Coordinator copies request details from portal email notification into Excel spreadsheet, then manually checks technician availability in Google Calendar, then calls tenant to confirm time slot
section_c_systems_handoffs.q12_human_decision_gates: Coordinator must determine urgency level (emergency vs routine) and match to available technician skill set before scheduling

section_d_failure_cost.q13_common_failures: Double bookings when calendar not refreshed, missed requests buried in email inbox, tenant no-shows because confirmation call was delayed, emergency requests treated as routine due to misread priority
section_d_failure_cost.q14_cost_if_slow_or_failed: Tenant complaints, negative reviews, lease non-renewals. Emergency delays can cause property damage (burst pipe sitting 2 days). Each missed SLA costs approximately $150 in tenant credits plus staff time for escalation handling.

section_e_priority.q15_one_thing_to_fix: Eliminate the manual copy-paste from portal to spreadsheet and auto-check technician availability

attachments.notes: Client stated they have 3 coordinators handling requests. Peak volume is Monday mornings. They estimate 15% of requests miss the 24-hour SLA for routine maintenance.
